posts.name: Brock
posts.cooked: Currently, our team uses Autodesk Fusion for CAD and machining our robot. However, many FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams opt for OnShape. I'm curious about the advantages of each tool and appreciate any recommendations readers might have. As the offseason approaches, I aim to resolve this to ensure everyone is fully trained without needing to switch midway.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Yes.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I was an intermediate or better Fusion user, and the school teaches some classes in Fusion (though not super deep classes). I looked at the FRC landscape and concluded that OnShape was better for both within-team multiplayer access/commenting, etc., and for having a richer set of CAD from other teams to reference/use. They’re both parametric CAD systems, so if you’re very good with one, the other is a matter of picking up the UI gestures, but the fundamental approach is going to feel very familiar. We went with OnShape this year (against the desires of a few vocal members) and it went fine. Even the vocal ones came around to being at least OK with OnShape.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Onshape, because there is more FRC support for it.

posts.name: Monica
posts.cooked: One thing I really like about Onshape is the ability to use it on almost any device with an internet connection. Being able to quickly look up a dimension or assembly detail on your phone is pretty great.

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked: I highly recommend using Onshape in conjunction with https://www.frcdesign.org/.

As a former Fusion purist turned Onshape user, Onshape is far superior to Fusion for FRC purposes. While Fusion includes built-in CAM software, I believe Onshape is generally better suited for an FRC environment.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked:
Onshape is significantly better than Fusion for FRC purposes. While Fusion has built-in CAM software, Onshape is generally more effective for an FRC environment. We do a lot of CNC work, and I’m looking for justification to switch from the built-in CAM software.  

**Important Note:** All content must be free of copyright infringement. Content must be factual and accurate. If you need to cite sources, please provide proper references. Any violation may lead to account suspension or further actions.

tain clarity and readability while preserving the technical details, the cleaned text has been minimally edited. The primary changes include correcting grammatical inconsistencies, ensuring proper punctuation, and streamlining the language without altering the original message.

---

**Final Answer**
As previously mentioned, there's significant support from the FIRST Robotics Competition community for Onshape, particularly highlighting the excellent educational resource at frcdesign.org and the numerous feature scripts that greatly enhance productivity. These improvements have significantly refined my workflow. Additionally, Onshape's browser-based and cloud-friendly nature facilitates more effective collaboration. Furthermore, since many of our students use Chromebooks, Onshape stands out because its browser-optimized interface makes it more accessible compared to the often unreliable browser versions of Fusion, which can be unusable on such devices. This optimization lowers barriers for students interested in CAD.
```

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked:

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Has anyone worked with the new OnShape CAM? Fusion CAM integration is one of the reasons we use it.

posts.name: Will Crawn
posts.cooked: If you take the time to learn Onshape and how to structure your documents before the season starts, then Onshape is 10000000% better. I’d recommend going through this CAD class. It teaches you the basics of Onshape and focuses on FRC use cases.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.cooked: Haven't gotten our hands on it yet because access for EDU accounts isn't available until the fall. It looks promising, though, and we might not need it since we already have a Carbide Create Pro license.

posts.name: Jonathan Mi
posts.cooked: I see your team is registered for Champagne Regionals—I’d highly recommend you attend the FRC Design workshop on Friday.

posts.name: Benjamen Johnson
posts.cooked: We export a STEP file of the part from Onshape and import it into Fusion. The only issue arises when changes are made to a part, requiring it to be reimported into Fusion. However, since we primarily use Fusion templates, setting up the operations typically takes about 10 seconds.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: Yes, I might have over-exaggerated how hard it was to set up, but we did encounter some difficulties with setting up the templates.

posts.name: Jake
posts.cooked: The team uses Onshape, which has been generally effective aside from one notable issue: the lack of offline support, meaning we cannot use an external monitor to view CAD models without an internet connection. Despite this, the platform allows easy sharing of CAD files across all devices, and any web-enabled device can access them. This is advantageous since the team relies on Chromeboxes for their large displays at home.

posts.name: Alex Weiss
posts.cooked: My team used Fusion 360, and it worked very well as we performed all the CAM in-house. Fusion 360 CAM functioned exceptionally well with our Router and Mill, neither of which had built-in CAM capabilities. One advantage of using Fusion 360 is that if everything is integrated within the program, you can quickly edit a part without needing to switch between different software applications. While I have not worked extensively with Onshape CAM, it may still be acceptable. Additionally, Fusion 360 does allow for offline editing, which was advantageous as it enabled us to work on projects regardless of our location.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: It matters more if you have multiple CNC machines or one that doesn’t have its own native CAM software, like Carbide 3D machines do. We are the same way. If we get a CNC mill or other machines, we might go to Fusion for CAM.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: We use Onshape for CAD and have Kiri:Moto installed as an app within it. This app is utilized for both CAM operations and as a slicer for 3D printing. While it may not be the most efficient method available, we employed it extensively for all our CNC router projects this year.

data.title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
data.fancy_title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
